ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual lecture with time for discussion at the end of each lecture
Each class had a virtual lecture and virtual seminar/discussion component.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about Chinese history and culture, and their evolution over the course of millenia. My skills in literary criticism, close reading, and intertextual comparison were also greatly improved.
I gained a lot of insight into the development of Chinese natural poetry, as well as a great understanding of how Chinese philosophy relates to nature across time.

I gained an appreciation for ancient Chinese literature, and I learned how to parse through poems that were written thousands of years ago for lessons and feelings that is still pertinent and common today.
I learned a great deal about the history and significance of nature in Chinese literature, especially poetry.

I gained a mental map of the chronology of Chinese poetry, as well as its subdivisions. I learned how to approach works in translation, how to write about them, and the ways in which literary influence can propagate across generations of writers and artists. I also had a chance to consider the role of writing in rationalizing encounters with nature.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The readings for this class provide a fascinating cross-section of Chinese history and culture throughout the millenia, and the in-class discussion of them highlights their place not only within that history and culture but also within the canon of literary scholarship surrounding it. Connections are also drawn between works not just within one class but across the entire course, which creates at least the appearance of a comprehensive examination of the corpus of literature on the topic. Additionally, many of the readings are fantastic works of art in and of themselves, which drives engagement with in-class discussions.
The lectures are fantastic, engaging, and well-organized. Furthermore, Prof. Chang is brilliant and a great lecturer.
This class was great, no improvements

Strengths: Professor Chang has great energy. She is always excited about the material, and her excitement is contagious. The poems are also beautifully written, and so many lessons can be learned from them.

Weaknesses: Because the course covers hundreds of years of literary works, it is sometimes difficult to understand the chronology of the literary works.
Very strong course. Something to add may have been a more guided approach to what we need to focus on in the readings.
The texts we read were highly interesting, and the instructor's knowledge and enthusiasm made the learning experience enjoyable and informative.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If the class had been designed as a lecture course, the class Zoom setup (former TA screen-sharing a daily handout while Professor Chang talked) might have been effective. However, it was often expressed that the class was designed as a seminar, and this setup did not faciliate student participation effectively.
Leaving time at the end of each lecture for class discussion/questions improved virtual engagement
Excellent engagement and adaptation given the conditions of the pandemic. Not much engagement outside of class though.

The online format worked well in general, but due to the limited number of participants that could be viewed at a time, it was hard to tell when a student was raising their hand to comment or ask a question.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course opened my eyes to an entire facet of the world to which I had had no prior exposure, in a style which was simultaneously endearing and informative. I would absolutely reccomend it to absolutely everyone.
Absolutely!
Yes, most interesting class I've taken at Yale

I would definitely recommend this course because the material is very interesting and Professor Chang does an incredible job of organizing it and facilitating meaningful discussions! I think this course is best geared to those who either speak Chinese, are interested in Chinese culture, enjoy reading poetry, have an interest in the natural world, or are fascinated by Buddhism, Taoism, or Confucianism.
I would recommend it because professor was so wonderful! Unfortunately for other students, she's retiring.

I feel very lucky to have taken this course during Prof. Chang's last year at Yale before retirement. I would recommend this course to another student for its illuminating content and engaging professor.
Yes, but this is the last time it's being taught by Prof. Chang so not sure what it will become.

        Man & Nature in Chinese Lit/Man & Nature in Chinese Lit TR
